topic.title: How is security maintained with a shared private key?
topic.body:
Hello,

I'm reading through the source for [ZeroBoard](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroBoard), and [ZeroTalk](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk) . I noticed in ZeroBoard that the private key is visible in the [source code](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroBoard/blob/master/publisher/add.php). If each user [starts sharing the site as they visit it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_2qK1IuOKJ51pgBvllZ9Yu7Au2l551t3XBgyTSvilew/pub?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000&slide=id.g30df42c44_2_107), then every user would have a copy of the sourecode, correct?

How does ZeroNet allow sites to self-publish without other users accessing the private key, and potentially signing malicious content?

Cheers.

1604066212_mirrored_harrisonturton_githu.body:
Ah, so the .php file would have to be hosted on a server? Is this how multi-user sites are managed - the site (shared to other users) sends a request to the server, which posts something to it's database, and then re-publishes the site? This can't be right, because that's centralised.

Are there any resources that I can read about distributed multi-user zites? I tried to go through the documentation and examples but I feel that it's barely touched on, unless there's something I missed.

Thanks for your help @krixano!
